Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A recently updated standard will apply to the upcoming release, and evidence of conformity is required
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The Mother Superior has asked the nun to lead a series of daily reflections for the entire community during an upcoming retreat.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints and technical documents spread before me, the clock ticking toward the project deadline. The new safety standard had just been released, and as the lead engineer, it was my responsibility to ensure our design met every requirement. The regulatory board would demand evidence of our compliance, and any oversight could mean costly delays or worse, a safety hazard. My phone buzzed with a message from the Mother Superior, a gentle reminder that I was to lead the daily reflections for the community retreat starting tomorrow. As a nun, I was expected to guide my sisters in spiritual study, to be present, thoughtful, and prepared. My heart pounded with anxiety—how could I devote myself fully to both? The weight of my dual commitments pressed down on me, each demanding my undivided attention, each vital in its own way. I stared at the flickering candle on my desk, torn between the world of precise measurements and the world of quiet contemplation, unsure how to honor both without failing one.
